Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: CMOS integrated piezoelectric vapor sensors
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to improve safety by detecting toxic chemicals. Toxic chemicals present risks in many sectors; examples include the oil and gas industry, food quality monitoring, waste management optimization, agricultural pest infestations, and even breath analysis for disease detection. This project will advance the development of a low-cost, low-power vapor sensing system, with an initial focus on the threat detection and air quality monitoring market. <br/><br/>This Small Business Technology Transfer Phase I project proposes a high sensitivity, micro-fabricated functionalized sensor. The proposed architecture fabricates a high-frequency bulk acoustic resonator directly on CMOS integrated circuits, enabling low-cost mass production and improves the noise characteristics of the sensor. This direct integration simplifies the architecture and allows for suppressed electrical noise and also enables fabrication of an array of highly specific sensors. The project's research objectives include receptor evaluation, resonator fabrication, receptor integration, and sensor testing to characterize the system in relevant applications.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this Phase I project goal is to develop a novel gas sensor with an unparalleled combination of size, power and cost while offering high detection performance. The proposed architecture fabricates high-frequency bulk acoustic resonators coated with receptors which permits selective gaseous molecule detection in a format compatible with low-cost, mass-production systems. The initial target of this technology is the detection of hazardous hydrocarbon leaks, namely methane emissions in the oil and gas and flammable refrigerant gasses in the Heating Ventilation Air Conditioning and Refrigeration (HVACR) market.

In summary, the key outcomes of this Phase I project are:

  1. Customer discovery has been completed, having performed 300+ interviews with potential customers. Through this process product market fit was validated and a beachhead point of entry was identified. Four system integrator customers were secured. 
  2. Supply chain has been secured. A semiconductor foundry has agreed to provide piezoelectric resonators for scaling up production as well as significantly increasing device performance compared with University-fabricated devices to date. Additionally, three receptor suppliers have been secured to provide materials with specificity to the targets of interest.
  3. Printed Circuit Board (PCB) sensors have been designed and constructed using the resonators supplied by the foundry. These PCBs have been utilized as a platform to perform receptor evaluation and proof of concept gas testing measurements in order to establish the feasibility of our approach.
  4. A gas testing setup has been built including a new gas testing chamber and necessary peripherals in order to perform high-quality measurements.
  5. The receptor deposition process has been optimized by performing a characterization of various solution densities, solvent materials, deposition time and pressure in order to ensure optimal sensing performance. The gas detection properties of two proprietary receptors have been obtained using the sensor PCB platform to evaluate their performance against target analytes of interest to the beachhead use-cases. 
  6. The receptor-coated PCB sensors have been measured to quantify gas detection performance against methane and carbon dioxide which are the target gasses of interest to the beachhead use cases in this proposed work. The measurements showed successful gravimetric gas detection utilizing receptor-sensitized resonator boards, verifying the feasibility of our approach and justifying moving forward with this Phase II project.

Speaking to the broader impacts stemming from the outcomes of this Phase I project, the technology proposed here ensures personnel safety from flammable gas leaks in industrial, commercial and residential facilities. Additionally, it contributes to combating climate change by tackling one of the leading sources of carbon emissions which are fugitive methane leaks from oil and gas facilities. Speaking to the commercial potential, the technology proposed enables the mitigation of methane and refrigerant leaks which constitute a significant market opportunity reflecting pain points in the oil and gas and HVACR markets respectively. Our innovation solves the most important technical issues that have held back the widespread adoption of pervasive gas sensing in Internet of Things (IoT) applications. As an enabling system, it can be utilized in a variety of other applications such as the detection of explosives, narcotics and chemical weapons, indoor air quality monitoring as well as diagnosis of disease via breath analysis. Based on the above, the proposed project has the potential to disrupt the market generating significant commercial and societal impact.
